reviewText: To be perfectly honest, I had higher expectations for this movie given that it stars the classic dynamic duo of Pegg and Frost, but I was somewhat slightly disappointed. I think the potential of the idea of a couple of British space geeks travelling to the US for a comic convention and coming across a real live space alien could have really been a side splitter! Don't get me wrong there are parts where it was funny, but I guess I came into this movie with my own preconceptions because to the two star actors' track records.For me, the character of Paul and his behaviour is true to character, in the sense that you would expect that kind of behaviour from an alien who has been living amongst people in a secret base somewhere for so many years... he's gotten slightly comfortable with human culture and understands the human mindset. Not sure I liked Seth Rogan voicing Paul... I think there are better voices out there... can't really name any right now, but if I really give it a think I'm sure I could come up with a few. Is it just me or is Paul slightly obsessed with showing his family jewels?Not sure I really liked or understood the scenes where Nick Frost is jealous of Paul for spending time with his best mate Simon Pegg, he's straight and he's jealous of another alien guy for spending time with his mate? Huh!? (upset, feeling let down, lonely, abandoned these I can understand)I did enjoy Kristen Wiig's character where she wants to break free and live freely, but is completely new to the whole thing... it's funny where she tries to curse.One tiff I can't seem to get over with this movie is that it is, in a sense, blasphemous... evolution! There is clear and obvious swipe at religion in this movie which I did not appreciate.Overall a funny movie, but if you really want to enjoy it you have to forget all preconceptions, especially those relating to movies like Shaun of The Dead and Hot Fuzz. Again, funny but not laugh out loud funny.
summary: Not Laugh Out Loud Funny AND....

reviewText: Two British nerds (who seem to be on their thirties) go to San Diego for the Comic-Con, apparently a very huge Comic Book convention. A running gag in the film is that everybody assumes incorrectly that these two are gays - though this is never stated, it is likely that these thirty-something losers are virgins. On their return trip, they decide to rent a huge van to visit sites in the US West related to UFO conspiracies (Area 51, Roswell). On the road, they find an actual alien, the Paul of the title, who is diminutive, grumpy and foulmouthed, among other things, and is on the run from some Man in Black types who has held him imprisoned in a secret base for decades. The three soon see themselves on the lam, not just from the US agents, but also from some rednecks and a Christian fundamentalist who believes they have kidnapped his grown one-eyed daughter. All this is funnier on paper than on film. The best part is the first fifteen minutes, with its pointed satire of Nerd culture. After that, the film loses steam.This is the first film I have seen from the British comic duo of Simon Pegg and Nick Frost (they wrote the film and starred in it), and I must say that I wasn't too impressed with them. The movie never reaches its potential and is only intermittently funny. Also, I must say that for a semi mainstream movie, its mockery of Christian people is pretty pointed and harsh.
summary: Some funny moments, but it never reaches its potential

reviewText: Paul is a movie about two English geeks who is visiting USA to go to Comic con and taking a road trip to America's UFO hot spots, soon however to fun little vacation turn rather bizarre as the geeks meet Paul, an escaped alien on the run from the government, the two Englishmen decides to help Paul get to the place where he will be picked up by his mother ship and so start a chaotic and hilarious romp of a movie which spew pop culture references left and right. In a way Paul is very similar to another geeks on the road movie, Fanboys, and as a geek myself I almost laughed myself to death watching this movie.I also have to hand it to the creators of this movie, they manage to take a story where you after a while have allot of different groups involved and create ordered and very entertaining chaos while still keeping the story on track. The characters are great and I found myself caring for them, the actors all do a great job and the music and visuals are just perfect. Paul himself is amazing, the animators did a great job with him and they added personality and soul to this CG character which I would compare in quality to Gollum from the Lord of the Rings movies.One aspect of the movie that some might react negatively to is that it makes rather harsh fun of Baptist Christians, Paul makes fun of other groups as well but then much more light hearted. To me I am fine with this but I just wanted to mention it as this is a aspect of the movie that some might be insulted by.My only real complaint about Paul is that at times the jokes do not work, most of the time the movie is very funny, however at time the fart, sex and butt jokes can become a little bit grating, this cost the movie one star from me, but Paul is still a very good movie, the effects are great, the story is great I think anyone would enjoy this movie and I warmly recommend it. If I was going to summon up Paul briefly it would be ET, if he swore, smoked and had the language of a drunk sailor and the kid where replaced with two grown science fiction enthusiasts and a crazy Baptist woman, if that concept sounds like something you might enjoy then Paul is for you.
summary: Geeks plus alien makes for one hilarious roadtrip

reviewText: Two potty-mouthed sci-fi nerds from England, potty-mouthed Kristin Wiig, and a potty-mouthed little gray alien named Paul (with voiceover by potty-mouthed Seth Rogen) ride around the desert in an RV while being chased by bumbling, potty-mouthed secret agents intent on returning Paul to Area 51 so his brain can be sucked out for research.  And there you have it.The decision to just say the F-word every three seconds in lieu of jokes is too bad, because it's a cute idea for a movie with some clever concepts:  a wise-ass alien with bad driving skills crashes his spaceship, gets picked up by the U.S. military and ends up being the source of all our stereotypes and notions about aliens on Planet Earth (except for the anal probe.  Paul disavows all knowledge of that one).PAUL has a good heart, unless you're one of those Christians who thinks the earth is 4,000 years old.  And PAUL's credentials are pretty hefty, with a cast of A-list actors, plus the actual voice of Steven Spielberg as he receives sci-fi filmmaking tips from Paul. But even with all that talent, PAUL, while ostensibly a sci-fi send-up, is little more than an extended chase scene with all the predictable conventions of chase movies.It's supposed to be a comedy, but I think I laughed twice.  The trailer has all the jokes.  Watch it a few times and you're good to go.
summary: The Trailer Has All The Jokes

reviewText: Simon Pegg & Nick Frost have made a career of simultaneously parodying and creating films of the genres they love. They did it masterfully with zombies in "Shaun of the Dead," and not quite as masterfully with action films in "Hot Fuzz." "Paul" is their take on the sci-fi genre and it falls somewhere between their previous two collaborations in terms of success. The film either goes for laughs in mostly slapsticky, crude ways, or relies on nods to previous genre films. The film's goal to cram in as many ball jokes and geek references as they can kind of leaves me wishing for some wittier dialogue like Pegg & Frost had in their BBC series "Spaced."  For sci-fi geeks this film is a no-brainer (Braiiiiinnnnsss! Sorry, bad zombie pun.), but non genre fans will likely find themselves wanting for laughs.

reviewText: Nothing could have prepared me for the nonstop hilariousness that is Paul!!!It's about two British comic book fans who, while visiting the desert and Area 51 in the hopes of witnessing an alien sighting, actually MEET an alien and... this is no ordinary alien to say the least, haha.  He's crude, sharp-witted, and highly advanced.  He says offensive things and blend in extremely well with human beings and acts totally American, and even has clever reasons why.  For example, the part where he says he HAS to look like a typical alien because that's the image and portrayal people have had of aliens for over 60 years.  Great writing there.  His ability to turn camouflage is exciting too.This is most definitely an adventure movie but I MUST warn viewers that the film is probably totally inappropriate for kids due to the amount of F words flying around (mostly from the alien himself!)  When the police eventually realize the two British guys are hoarding an alien, this is when the chase is on and the gang constantly finds themselves trying to escape from the law and hide out somewhere.By FAR my favorite part is when the alien was having a discussion with a woman who gets picked up along the way about the existence of God.  The alien actually manages to convince the woman that God isn't real to the point she not only believes him, but completely changes her attitude and then goes around acting incredibly obnoxious with her choice of swear words, lol.  This leads to plenty of hilarious moments.The entire storyline is brilliantly told however, so despite the many obnoxious segments, you'll be sure to enjoy a comedy centering around aliens and especially the way the one alien interacts with people.  I highly recommend it.
summary: Paul... what a deceiving name for a hilarious film!

Along comes Simon Pegg and Nick Frost, tourists from England, who become his new BFF's and try to make that happen. Kristen Wiig is very good as the religious girl who gets some eye-opening (literally) views.I liked seeing Jason Bateman, Jeffrey Tambor, Jane Lynch and other fine actors do their thing. The special effects are wonderful, the sly (or blantant) illusions to other movies are great, the acting is top notch and the story line, if used before, is still worth seeing again. Paul's voice, Seth Rogen, is good. We go through most the movie wondering who "the big guy" is and when we find out, it is just freakin' perfect. Truly.

reviewText: Forgive me if this sounds a lot like the Roger Ebert review but honestly it appears we had a near identical reaction to the movie. Paul is an alright movie. It's fun to watch Simon Pegg and Nick Frost together. It's well shot and a good movie to see in theaters, especially with friends, which is what I did. The idea of an RV road trip works well theatrically but also feels a little underwhelming at times because the movie seems not to have enough ideas. As Ebert pointed out, the ComicCon stuff is pretty funny. The film is very confident in that area and would have been better if it stayed with material it was completely comfortable with. Instead, they bring in an alien character, who has a good introduction and some promise since Seth Rogan is involved but never really takes off. I'm 100% with Ebert that the alien is too ordinary, and watching the movie I kept thinking "are they going to do anything different with it than it being Seth Rogan? This is pretty human for an alien." So the movie has a premise, but doesn't make much progress. It's almost a good movie, and maybe one more rewrite would have done the trick. Just a little more imagination into the alien character. What's there is good, but it won't bowl you over.It serves this movie to have been a miss, they ripped off made-for-TV-USA-original-movie Beer Money! At least I was amused by the similarities. The performances are solid. I watched some making-of feature and the cast looked like they were having a ton of fun. Sigourney Weaver is always welcome, and I was delighted to hear Steven Spielberg.2 and a 1/2 out of 4
summary: Premise and Promise but not enough Payoff

reviewText: Brief disclaimer about myself...yes, I have my own strongly held Christian based religious beliefs but I believe everybody is entitled to their own views and opinions. I can take a joke, as long as it's good. I am also a huge Simon Pegg fan...I consider "Shaun of the Dead" to be one of the greatest films ever made and to be a truly inspiring film. Being a big Simon Pegg fan, I ignored the negative reviews for Paul, especially the ones accusing it of "religion bashing".  I figured it was just some fundementalist Christians, who are even more uptight than me. Unfortunately, that is exactly what the film was, and the worst "sin" of all is that it is not even remotely funny or clever. A massive collection of talent couldn't save the film from becoming a few actors' diatribes against any and all religious beliefs (not just Christian). The few funny gags have been seen countless times on commercials, the plot was not well developed, nor was the leading villian, leaving it a thinly veiled rant against religion with some Comicon nerd humor thrown in. Being a Simon Pegg/Nick Frost pet project, it basically serves to advocate their atheist views and ridicule anybody with religious beliefs of any kind; imploring people to drink, have sex, and do drugs whenever one can (to each their own). Even though its sole purpose is to insult mine and everybody else's religious views, I could forgive all this as long as it was intellegent and funny...but it's not. It's basically "Battlefield Earth" for atheists. The humor is lowbrow, which I am usually fine with, as long as it's witty, but it's stuff I would have thought up as a 14 year old. If you're sensitive of your religious views being insulted, this is not for you. If your an atheist looking for an intellegent film to advance your views, this is also not for you. Even if you're just looking for an entertaining film, this again is unfortunately not for you. It was a colossal waste of talent and a major bomb. Sincerely hope Pegg and Frost redeem themselves with their next film because this one sucked.

reviewText: Simon Pegg and Nick Frost have basically become comedic icons over the past seven years. Along with director Edgar Wright, Pegg and Frost were introduced to most Americans through both Shaun of the Dead and Hot Fuzz. Each of the British actors found success venturing off on their own even though Pegg seemed to have more successful outings. Pegg playing Scotty in J.J. Abrams Star Trek reboot is probably what he's known best for these days, but Paul is the first time we've seen the two reunited since Hot Fuzz. Would it be worth the wait? Could Pegg and Frost make a great film without fellow UK collaborator Edgar Wright? If you're thinking of any answer other than, "Yes," then you're highly mistaken.There really is no reason not to like this film if you enjoyed Superbad or basically any film Simon Pegg or Nick Frost were a part of. The writing doesn't seem to be quite as polished as when Edgar Wright is also included in the equation, but it doesn't take anything away from the entertainment factor of the film. In fact, one of the highlights of the film is how much homage to other great sci-fi films is actually included in the film. Some reviews are saying that there was too much, but I thought it fit the overall tone of the film incredibly well. My personal favorite was the reference made to a specific James Cameron film (hint: it's not Avatar) after it's revealed who's been giving Agent Zoil (Jason Bateman) orders, but Steven Spielberg's cameo is a close second.The supporting cast is just as fantastic as the main one. Simon Pegg and Nick Frost are, of course, the highlight. The ongoing gag of everyone thinking they're a gay couple somehow manages to remain humorous every time someone comes back to it. Seth Rogen was the perfect choice for Paul. While Pegg and Frost have admitted in interviews that they originally had an older actor in mind for the voice of Paul, Rogen brings the stoner humor he's become associated with to an extraterrestrial being with ease. Trying to imagine someone else in the role is nearly impossible. Kristen Wiig also steals quite a few scenes mostly due to her unique use of vulgarity. However, the scenes involving Bill Hader, Joe Lo Truglio, and Jason Bateman are just as great as the ones featuring the main cast. Bateman's Agent Zoil seems to be trying to take this assignment seriously while Haggard (Hader) and O'Reilly (Truglio) are constantly getting in his way due to them not taking their jobs seriously.The film seemed slightly reminiscent of Pineapple Express. Other than the fact that actors in the cast of Paul were also in Pineapple Express, Pineapple Express had a lot more action in it than the trailers let on. It was almost just as much as an action film as it was a comedy. Paul is the same way, but it brings some drama into the mix as well. It's certainly a comedy first, but it doesn't take long for you to get sucked into the film's explosive action. There's actually a little bit of heart to the film as well as the drama comes into play when the fate of a few of these characters you've grown to love over the past hour and forty minutes becomes questionable.Paul covers nearly all of its bases just in the amount of genres the film seems to cram in one film. It's a sci-fi comedy on the surface with one of its main characters being completely animated while also throwing a little bit of action, drama, and adventure in for good measure. The film seems to spend just as much time making you laugh as it does knocking you out of your chair with all of the car chases and gunfire heavy action sequences before surprising you by pulling at your heartstrings in the finale. If you enjoyed Superbad, Pineapple Express, Shaun of the Dead, or Hot Fuzz, then Paul is a must see. Paul is an adventure that'll suck you in and make you wish any of the trips you've taken through the desert were half this entertaining and hilarious.
summary: A 'furry nice' R-rated comedy filled with laughs and plenty of homage to films you love

reviewText: Clive and Graeme are just two Brits attending the San Diego Comi-Con, living their childhood dream by touring the southwestern U.S. in search of alien hotspots.  Little do they know that their trip is about to become a whole lot more dangerous...when they run into an actual alien, a smart-mouthed runaway named Paul.  He's trying to escape "the big man" and reunite with his species...and he's bringing his two new-found friends along for the ride.There's nothing about PAUL that is entirely new or original, which actually works in the film's favor; fans of the genre can simply watch it and enjoy, and newcomers have enough to keep them interested.  The acting is top-notch; Simon Pegg and Nick Frost still have great chemistry; this is their film, no doubt.  Seth Rogen's Paul is believable and entertaining; I'm not a huge Rogen fan, but he certainly know show to deliver a good line.  Kristen Wigg, as a devout Christian "born again" under Paul's tutelage, is amusing; Bill Heder and Joe Lo Truglio are great as a pair of Men in Black, with Jason Bateman being a standout as their superior.  The film also features a few great minor roles for John Caroll Lynch, Jane Lynch, David Koechner, Jesse Plemons, Steven Spielberg (yep), Blythe Danner, and an actress I won't name, though if you're familiar with her you'll identify her pretty early on (her entrance is still bada** though).  The script is solid (there are a lot of references to previous sci-fi films, some subtle, some not), and Greg Mottola's direction was, as usual, confident and sure.  If PAUL has any strikes against it, it's that the film is a bit too polished; it could afford to be rougher around its edges, given its R-rated (though not over-the-top) material.  Still, the film is enjoyable and entertaining, and is certainly a worthy entry in Pegg and Frost's canon.

reviewText: Was I ever glad I bumped up against whatever HBO channel was showing PAUL recently. In particular I enjoyed the zingers Paul hurls at those who insist extraterrestrials don't exist; he gives them all the proverbial middle finger. reviewText: I really enjoyed this movie, an homage to loving sci-fi and a look at the fan culture. (note: I watched the unrated version.) When I picked this movie to watch, I wasn't really paying much attention to the talent, but to the story: two Brits come to the US to attend ComicCon, then go on a road trip to visit some of America's famous UFO locales, including (but not limited to) Roswell and Area 51. At the very beginning of their road trip, they run into an alien named Paul. He looks exactly like the stereotypical alien with his big green head and big eyes and skinny body. But he has abilities - he can become invisible - and he has some, shall we say, bad habits, including smoking dope and drinking beer. And cursing. A lot.The story that follows is at turns amusing (all of Paul's cursing), at turns thoughtful (Paul's debate against an all-knowing God); sometimes action-packed (being chased by the government) and sometimes just silly (Paul pretending to be a statue of an alien). It's also full of references to classic sci-fi movies, which the true fan will really enjoy (and the sorta fan won't notice or miss).Now to talk about the talent: the writers - and main actors - are Simon Pegg and Nick Frost, a pair I first saw in the silly but fun Brit TV ComedySpaced: The Complete Series.  (Frost is also great in the sci-fi Brit TV ComedyHyperdrive.)  They obviously had a lot of fun writing and starring in the movie. My favorite actor in the movie, tho, is Jason Bateman. He usually plays such goofy characters, that to see him play a very focused, driven government agent was quite refreshing. I also enjoyed Jane Lynch as an storekeeper selling alien tchochkys; Kristen Wiig as Ruth, daughter of a Bible-thumper; and of course, the actress who plays The Big Guy (you'll just have to watch the movie to find out!). The only downer for me was the person who voiced Paul: Seth Rogen. Rogen is a fine actor, but every time Paul opened his mouth, I only saw Rogen, not the alien he was meant to portray.I also think I probably should have watched the theatrical version - the unrated one is just a tad too long.4.5 stars.

reviewText: Paul is an oddly subdued comedy, but could have been an over-the top-disaster, so I can forgive it for it's sometimes lack of lunacy.Pegg and Frost (both of Shaun of the Dead and Hot Fuzz fame) play English friends visiting America starting with San Diego's Comic Con and continuing with an RV trek across the U.S., visiting famous UFO sites.  Along the way they encounter the real thing, (almost literally) running into Paul, an alien who has been a guest of our government since the 1940's.  He's on the run and heading for Wyoming to meet up with a ship ready to take him back home.We learn that, over the years, Paul has been giving advice to our government, movie studios, and other sources, contributing heavily to the pop culture of the last fifty years (this leads to a pretty funny cameo from a well-known Hollywood director).  He looks like the familiar basic alien because he was used as the model.  Paul likes to smoke, drink, curse, and joke around.  And he can be a douche.  He's a uniquely American alien.Naturally, the boys agree to help Paul, meeting Kristin Wiig (who nearly steals the whole show and has some of the best lines), redneck morons, a bible-thumping nutcase, and eccentric government spooks along the way.  Bateman and Weaver play it straight, but have some amusing conversations chasing our heroes.Director Mottola doesn't have the whimsical touch of Pegg and Frost's usual director of choice, Edgar Wright (Shaun of the Dead, Hot Fuzz, and Scott Pilgrim vs. the World), but he does have a pretty decent comedy pedigree in Superbad and makes Paul a lot of fun.It's not the holy grail of comedy we're used to from Pegg and Frost (who also wrote the screenplay), but it's an entertaining and playful piece of quiet schtick.

reviewText: Judge Patrick Naugle, DVD Verdict-- Now comes Paul, which isn't as good as either of their previous efforts but still gets more right than it gets wrong. Pegg and Frost collaborated on the screenplay while Greg Mottola (who helmed the amusing Superbad) took over the directing reigns from Wright. The finished product is a goofy, silly slacker alien comedy that never takes itself too seriously. It's hard not to have an endearing love for a movie that features a lot of jokes about an alien's 'junk'.Paul's best laughs come from its smaller moments, especially between Pegg and Frost. At this point it feels as if the two actors are (to steal a Kevin Smith phrase) "heterosexual life mates," and their banter is often side splitting and touching at the same time. It's rare that a movie can take two actors and make you believe they are best friends; since Pegg and Frost are buddies in real life, it's an easy transition that works in the movie's favor. Seth Rogan as the title character is funny, although it's sometimes hard to look past Rogan's very dense and familiar persona and see a character behind Paul's eyes. It's to Rogan's credit that after a while I was able to get into Paul's groove and actually care about his eventual outcome.Another reason for Paul's success is that it features a talented supporting cast. Saturday Night Live seems to have its paws all over this film, with Kristen Wiig and Bill Hader taking on supporting roles (both are funny, though Wiig's character grates after a while). Jason Bateman is at his deadpan best as an agent trying to find Paul; Bateman is quickly becoming the go-to guy in blockbuster comedies lately, and for good reason--he's funny. Amusingly, there are two very funny cameos in the film that will tickle movie buffs, neither of which I will spoil in this review except to say that their connection to this film makes a lot of sense once you see and hear them.Paul's only real misstep is that it sometimes revels too heavily and lengthily in slacker humor, almost at times to the breaking point. Pot jokes abound (note to filmmakers and Seth Rogan: we get it, you like to smoke weed...now let's move on) and the profanity in the film, while never offensive, wears thin especially with Kristen Wiig's character. The screenplay sometimes oversteps its bounds by allowing jokes to pop up one too many times (characters fainting after seeing an alien is funny once; four times, not so much) and taking too many malicious jabs at religion (again, amusing at first but that wears thin fast). Yet, these are mostly nitpicks; what the movie does, it usually does very well.I readily enjoyed Paul; it's a movie that doesn't try too hard to be likable and, while it's not a classic, it's still a lot of fun with good effects work (the character of Paul is believable even when you know he's just an onscreen computer graphic) and enough sci-fi geekiness to placate fanboys and regular viewers. Here's hoping Pegg and Frost keep making movies; they're a couple of true diamonds in the rough.Paul is presented in 2.35:1 widescreen in 1080p resolution. Universal's work on this hi-def picture is excellent and pleasing to the eye. The movie isn't overly flashy (even though it has its fair share of special effects work), but even without all the razzmatazz (finally I got to use the word "razzmatazz" in a sentence!) this is an excellent looking picture. There's nary a speck of dust, dirt or any other imperfection in the image. Whatever you may think of this movie, the fact remains that Paul sparkles on Blu-ray.The soundtrack is presented in a fun, rollicking DTS-HD Master Audio 5.1 mix that features heavy use of the side, rear and front speakers. There are many moments during Paul where the action dictates a lot of surround sound effects that are both exciting and comedic (especially the music score by David Arnold, who also coincidentally composed the score for Independence Day). Dialogue, effect and music are all evenly recorded and well mixed. Overall both the video and audio presentations are top notch. Also included on this disc are soundtracks in DTS 5.1 in French and Spanish, as well as English, French and Spanish subtitles.There are a fair amount of extra features included on this edition of Paul, including an amusing commentary track by director Greg Mottola, producer Nira Park and actors Nick Frost, Simon Pegg and Bill Hader; a rather extensive 'making of' featurette titled "Between the Lightening Strikes: The Making of Paul" (which included cast and crew interviews and behind the scenes footage); eight behind-the-scenes featurettes ("RV Doorway: The Cast of Paul On-Location," "Runway Santa Fe: An Interview with Nancy Steiner," "Smithereens," "5th Date Level Direction: The Cast on Greg Mottola," "Mexico Zero: The Locations of Paul," "The Many Pauls," "Paul the Musical" and "The Traveler Beagle) that highlight everything from locations to CGI effects to the casting of the film; a 15 minute featurette on the visual effect of the film ("The Evolution of Paul"); a very short featurette on the Jeffrey Tambor character Adam Shadowchild ("Who The Hell is Adam Shadowchild"),\; a blooper reel; "Simon's Silly Faces" (exactly what it sounds like);six galleries of photos and behind-the-scenes snapshots; some trailers and TV spots; BD Live features and a bonus digital copy/DVD of the film.Note: two versions of the film are included, a 104 minutes theatrical cut and a 110 minutes "Director's Cut."-Full review at dvdverdict,com

reviewText: After an extremely slow start, which almost plays like a home movie, the story finally picks up after the two hapless vacationers (Pegg & Frost) pick up the desperate alien on the loose, Paul.  The alien in question has out served his usefulness in providing the government with information, now they want his body and brain for experimentation. It is odd though, that the two writers Pegg & Frost presumed that spewing a lot of obscenities would automatically be considered funny and thought it a challenge to piece together unlikely combinations of such.  After a lot of this, it just became repetitious nonsense not to be confused with wit, making the dialog incredibly inconsistent.  This movie is, in turns, sweet, nasty, silly, maudlin, vulgar, irreverent, rude, and offensive.  They were doing all right until they decided to take some unnecessary potshots at Christianity.  At this point in time, there are specific religions that most people are afraid to mock and distain for fear of genuine retribution.  Christianity is not one of these and as such is routinely scorned by filmmakers with a definite loathing they feel the need to demonstrate every chance they get.I didn’t mind watching Paul once but can’t see myself watching it again as the first experience wasn’t that great.  Almost funny is not funny enough.

reviewText: Paul is like a mix between the "arrested development" male comedies so prevalent nowadays and E.T. It makes for a great mix. The film stars an alien whose name is Paul. reviewText: It's mildly funny, but unfortunately not too smart - like "Dogma", it's unable to get past brain-dead puns (Agent Zoil's first name, for example) and unintelligent cliched caricatures about creationists, who are somewhat - well, a lot - abused in this movie. Tellingly, the movie's only reply to their beliefs is "Paul is an alien and he says we evolved, so there - you guys are idiots!" I was hoping for a smarter, or at least funny argument. Sadly, all we get is the above, like Richard Dawkins' baseless insistence that he is right, yet refusing to debate the most compelling argument for intelligent design - irreducible complexity - because "I'm not an expert". You don't say!Paul, the all-knowing alien, seems completely unaware that some of the most famous believers in intelligent design were, in fact, atheists - distinguished scientists such Fred Hoyle and Allan Sandage (who later became a Christian) who, through their scientific work, found "everything here by chance" too anti-scientific and too puerile to believe. Hoyle's amazement at the evidence for design led him to conclude "A common-sense interpretation of the facts suggests that a superintellect has monkeyed with physics, as well as with chemistry and biology, and that there are no blind forces worth speaking about in nature. The numbers one calculates from the facts seem to me so overwhelming as to put this conclusion almost beyond question." (Being an atheist, he theorized that life came from outer space.) Agnostics such as molecular biologist Michael Denton have similarly found evolutionism to be anti-scientific in nature, whereas former believers in evolution such as Michael Behe have instead found evidence for a Designer in their study of life at the molecular level. Lifelong atheist philosopher Antony Flew is another:There Is a God: How the World's Most Notorious Atheist Changed His MindHowever, those who thought Dogma was "smart" will probably not even be cognizant of the above issues. They will scratch their heads, gigglingly vote Not Helpful, and move on. So much for Questioning Authority and being an independent thinker :)Apparently, the movie also thinks that believing in evolution will result in obsession with sex and profanity. And marijuana. Perhaps they are right, I don't know. Strangely, they didn't mention another result - war, torture, imprisonment, and mass murder to the tune of 120 million (ask Hitler, Stalin, and Mao, or seeFrom Darwin to Hitler: Evolutionary Ethics, Eugenics, and Racism in Germany) - ruins the mood, I guess, or afraid of giving ideas to impressionable youth like Jeffrey Dahmer or the Columbine shooters, who did mention Darwinism as rationale for their actions.Oh. Sorry. I suppose there are some who are totally unaware of the Hitler-Darwin connection. Just for you:Evolutionist Sir Arthur Keith: "The German Fuhrer as I have consistently maintained, is an evolutionist; he has consciously sought to make the practice of Germany conform to the theory of evolution" (Keith, Evolution and Ethics, 230). There, all done. We may continue.Also, inexplicably, the movie doesn't bash Muslims at all, who also believe in - ah, wait a minute. That would be dangerous, wouldn't it? Always easy to slap someone who's supposed to turn the other cheek. But not too brave, natch. Also pokes fun at the only politically acceptable classes to mock, such as rednecks with trucks. But what's a little racism and intolerance in Hollywood? All in good fun, as long as you follow the rules.Anyone who has ever been interested in UFOs will probably like this movie. I enjoyed the main characters' enjoyment of their worlds of UFOs and Comic-Con. It takes a while to ramp up, though, and the middle stretch gets tedious, but if you're not too demanding (and not too worried about science) it's likeable enough for the most part. A couple of characters - their pursuers - take unexpected turns, which are not altogether explicable or satisfying. Why did these lovable goofballs suddenly become nasty? Dunno, but they waste a fair amount of goodwill invested in them.So, if you're willing to put aside your brain for a bit, or if you lack it in the first place, you'll probably have some fun with this movie. Unless ...It's quite possible that the writers are mocking viewers who are cheering the creationist-bashing. (Not to mention, as they cheer, the movie potentially exposes their hypocrisy regarding tolerance, reason, and being informed.) Because, for all his other traits, Paul ... Is a Christ-figure! The idea of sacrificial healing, the healer taking into himself the injuries and diseases of others, is a deeply Christian concept. Pre-Christian heroes were conquerors who destroyed their enemies, not self-sacrificial healers (seekers of knowledge, seeThe Book that Made Your World: How the Bible Created the Soul of Western Civilization). So we cheer Paul as he heals, giving of himself that others may be healed, yet mock the only religio-philosophical foundation for cheering this as a virtue, not a weakness. And although Ruth is "freed" from her religion by Paul, her religion - as portrayed by her father as judgmental and warped - is more representative of religions like modern environmentalism, e.g. Al Gore calling global warming doubters "racists", global warming believers excommunicating and censoring doubters, recycling nuts tut-tutting their acquaintances for not being good recyclers, and neo-liberals calling for and perpetrating actual physical violence against their "enemies".Is this far-fetched? Dan Brown mischievously outed elitist critics who praised his "accurate" books as uninformed know-nothings who apparently were easy prey to easily-debunkable conspiracy theories. Perhaps this movie is doing the same. But I'm just pulling your chain, actually. Pretty sure the writers were clueless about actual science.You may ask, "It's a comedy! Why not just enjoy it for the laughs?" I would answer with a question: do you agree with the saying, "It's funny because it's true?" I do. When comedy departs from truth, it loses its funniness, because your brain keeps interfering. Allow me to illustrate.Let's suppose you believe Obama is the best President ever, and this movie is a comedy about him. In the movie, Obama is portrayed as a clueless incompetent who never accomplished anything before becoming President, and wastes billions of taxpayer money on ill-advised schemes which strangely benefit his cronies. Probably untrue, of course, but stay with me. Suppose the jokes about his incompetence and corruption are hilarious. You could not enjoy it as a comedy, since you see it as an attack piece on the President, not a comedy. Furthermore, you would be concerned that clueless viewers will enjoy it and think they are "learning" something about Obama that is false.Same thing.

reviewText: What had happened was, I got spoiled by Simon Pegg, Nick Frost, and director Edgar Wright's three prior screen excursions.Spaced: The Complete Series,Shaun of the Dead, andHot Fuzz [Blu-ray/DVD Combo + Digital Copy] all featured characters who - no matter how bizarre the stuff going on around them was - were likable enough and believable enough that you got invested in them. SHAUN OF THE DEAD and HOT FUZZ were this trio's take on, respectively, the zombie sub-genre and the cop buddy film. The TV show, SPACED, was their nerdgasmic homage to pop culture. With PAUL (but without Wright), Pegg and Frost take on the sci-fi genre and fail to soar. I'm rating PAUL a better than average 3 out of 5 stars. I liked it. I didn't love it. PAUL doesn't have the smarts of their other collaborations. Or the brilliant, irrepressible sense of humor.Clive Gollings (Frost) and Graeme Willy (Pegg) are two affable Brits who've crossed the waters on holiday. The film opens with their having a grand time of it at the San Diego Comic Con, after which they embark, via RV, on a leisurely road trip with pit stops to various UFO landmarks along America's heartland. Life imitates nerdy wishful thinking when, one evening, Clive and Graeme stumble onto Paul, a little green extraterrestrial what had done a bunk from a top secret government facility, wherein he had been kept prisoner for the past sixty years. And them relentless government agents are in hot pursuit. Paul doesn't want to probe anyone as much as he desperately wants off this God's little rock. Clive and Graeme become his unwilling accomplices.If Paul and Spielberg's E.T. had attended the same school, Paul would've been the one chillin' in the back of the class and playing the fool, while E.T. would've been seated in the front, conscientiously jotting down test notes from which Paul can later copy. Paul is the sort of "hip" alien we see more of nowadays, the alien with attitude. He wears flipflops, he smokes, he swears amiably... he is, God help us, a wisecracking slacker alien, and impeccably, digitally rendered. Today, I miss E.T. and his unassuming grace more than ever. And everytime I heard Seth Rogen's deep voice coming out of Paul's beak, I just kept getting thrown off.It would've been okay, though, if that had been the only bother. But it's not. I dunno. Is the secret ingredient Edgar Wright? Does he have to helm a Pegg and Frost picture in order for it to float our boat? PAUL is a surprisingly lackluster film. It's pretty concerning that the screenplay credits go to Pegg and Frost, because the quality of the writing falls several tiers below what I expect of them. Is this their stab at a mainstream audience? Or did Universal coerce them to cater their comedy to what's safe? I smiled occasionally, but laughed rarely. PAUL goes for the obvious gags. There's a particularly brutal running bit with Kristen Wiig's one-eyed, uber-religious character evolving into a rampant potty mouth. Maybe a scene or two with a naive soul letting rip with the cusswords may be funny. But the movie goes to this well time and again. I miss Kristen Wiig's deadpan sarcasm. What I don't miss is Sigourney Weaver's cameo in the third act. She isn't good here.The stuff that works, it's because of Simon Pegg and Nick Frost and their buddy chemistry. They make the film watchable. It's a pleasure watching these two long-time pals playing off each other. You sense the high comfort level there. And the few times that the film - or Universal Studios - allows them to be themselves, the results are a riot. I enjoy the shift in dynamics. This time out, Nick Frost expands beyond the idiot sidekick role. There's even a chance that his writer character may be the smarter of the pair. For his part, Simon Pegg is so self-deprecating and down-to-earth that you can't help but like him. PAUL has its moments, except that these guys have set their standards so high that you have to call them out when they submit mediocre work. And PAUL is far from their best. I frankly can't wait for Pegg and Frost to reunite with Edgar wright for THE WORLD'S END, the third of their "Three Flavours Cornetto Trilogy," projected to be released sometime in 2014. Edgar Wright, look at you, dude, suddenly an indispensable cog. As far as PAUL, I say catch it when it's on cable. Alf has a lot to answer for.This DVD gives you the option to play the film's theatrical version or the unrated version. It has the following bonus stuff:- Audio Commentary on the theatrical version only, with director Greg Mottola, producer Nira Park, and actors Simon Pegg, Nick Frost, and Bill Hader- Bloopers (00:10:53 minutes)- Evolution of PAUL - the process of animating Paul (00:15:06 minutes)- "Simon's Silly Faces" - this is pretty self-explanatory (00:01:22 minutes)- "Who the Hell is Adam Shadowchild?" - a bit of the spotlight on Jeffrey Tambor's scene-stealing sci-fi author character (00:02:12 minutes)- Galleries: Photos, Storyboards, and Posters

reviewText: I can't believe the people who gave this piece of trash a five-star rating -- totally clueless!DO NOT waste your money on this toilet-bowl of a movie, I'm giving you fair warning! If it were a freebee for Amazon Prime customers, then go ahead, waste your time, you can always turn it off after the fist ten minutes without monetary loss.So here's the review, I'm going to start with the few decent points about the film (I'll try to be as charitable as possible).Concept:  Frankly, I did like the basic concept, it was somewhat along the lines of Galaxy Quest (an excellent film with solid A-list stars like Tim Allen & Allen Rickman).Plot: Alien survey ship crashed on Earth back in 1947. Alien pilot befriended by 11 yr. old girl then taken away by "authorities".  Alien held captive & interrogated. Over the years, provides authorities ideas about how to soften the blow to the human race when the rest of his kind arrives.  One funny clip showing alien on speaker-phone advising Steven Spielberg on the making of "E.T". Alien fails to reveal secrets behind certain advance technologies, authorities decide he's no longer a valuable asset & decide to dissect him.  Alien escapes & runs into two hapless / clueless sci-fi geeks from the U.K.  Geeks are on a once-in-a-lifetime road trip to visit all the famous UFO sites in the States; they cross paths with escaped alien during a night-time highway crash.  Alien needs to get to special "place" (says, "you'll know it when you see it") where he can signal for a rescue ship. Geeky guys agree to take him. Bad guys pursue alien & new friends.  That's pretty much the entire movie. To be fair, I like the plot as a basis for a nice family-friendly funny-film / good date-flick.  Sadly, it all goes downhill from there.I condemn this film for two reasons: first,the incessant need for 7-th grade locker room humor, even-more-infantile toilet-humor and non-stop gratuitous foul language.  There were a few bits where MAYBE it was funny ONCE! But the writers just kept it up all throughout the film -- it just wasn't funny to thinking-people!The second problem was the use of blatant stereotyped fundamentalist Christian characters. It's ok to make some brief political commentary then move on, but they just kept bashing these people all throughout the film, right up to the very end.  Why was that necessary?  What did it add to the film? Once again -- NOT FUNNY! What do you think would have happened had they depicted a Muslim, Native American, Asian American or Mexican American family in this manner.  Hollywood leftists never tire of telling us how "sensitive" and "respectful" they are when it comes to cultural diversity -- unless, of course, you happen to be Christian.You can make political / social commentary in a constructive way. The writers could have allowed the antagonists to evolve towards some new world view having room for both points of view.  Instead, we see Paul, the alien, depicted as a comical "demon" trying to seduce a devoutly-Christian girl from her faith, her belief in God, when the issue was the fundamentalist life style forced upon her.  Alas, we have to endure this thinly-veiled theological raping throughout the entire film. It was demeaning and just plain uncomfortable to watch at times; the entire sub-plot added absolutely nothing to the primary story line.As an alternative, the writers could've allowed Paul to be (like his Biblical namesake) a kind of teacher, someone to help the girl see the world from a different perspective; someone who shows her how to embrace and strengthen her faith in a new way by adopting a broader context beyond the limited belief-system she grew up with. They could've spent a minute on the father and what made him the way he was. But the audience was only allowed to see daddy as some deranged Bible-thumping kook in a beat-up Chevy pickup. THAT'S PATHETIC WRITING!Heavy message? Sure,but really GOOD comedy writers can pull off something that's philosophically deep while still doing straight-up comedy.  They did in in Galaxy Quest: a funny movie that switched to drama before you realized you were sucked into it. We see a bunch of has-been T.V. stars well past their prime, trying to make a buck at shopping mall openings and sparsely-attended sci-fi conventions. Suddenly, they're propelled into an alien world engaged in a life-and-death struggle for survival. Our motley crew of Hollywood-has-beens are given the choice to go back to their boring lives or stay and fight with their new alien companions -- they chose to fight! "Never surrender, never give up!" That one simple scene goosed what was a decent funny-picture into overdrive that kept the audience engaged to the end. There was nary a foul word spoken during the entire film and it had broad appeal to all age groups over 12 yrs. Though it flopped in ticket sales (poor marketing) it did well in the DVD market and stands as a cult-favorite today.Paul lacked all those qualities; the writers thought it was easier to go for cheap gutter-humor laughs, foul language and blatant stereotyping.  I truly felt sorry for some of the actors; they could have done a better job if the director had simply thrown out the script and told them to ad lib their scenes instead.

reviewText: The cast is so wonderful I don't even want to single out anybody.  They are all fantastic.  Bateman and Weaver are the only ones I was familiar with.  (Yeah, I've missed some good flicks in recent years.)  But I can't think of anyone that didn't shine in this.The characters are written with a wonderful variety of quirks and motivations.  The writing is fun and clever and creates hilarious homages to the sci fi genre.  I love the humor they had with swearing throughout the film, but especially with the repressed character that suddenly decides she needs to learn how to swear.  This sweet film ends on an up note that will appeal to American audiences.  But it is not for children.There are some reviews that say this is an anti-Christian film.  As a person of faith I say: baloney!  The type of "faith" this film mocks is a particularly narrow minded Christianity that thinks the Earth is 4,000 years old.It was interesting that Paul at the end has a scene in which he emulates Christ in a particular way.  I think there are plenty of Christians that will notice that and be reminded that there is a gulf between what we talk about and how we act towards others.On the other hand I don't want to give the impression this is a film with a deep message.  The standard "science vs. faith" dichotomy is a silly assumption in my opinion and the film seems to adopt it even though it doesn't carry that very far.  Picking a fundamentalist evangelical as a foil for a pro-science/anti-religion posture is too easy.  This is lazy, "pop" philosophy but the writers never intended to wade deep into these issues.  The film is meant to be light and not heavy.This is a light comedy from Hollywood.  It is not a serious treatment of Christianity, atheism or any such topics.  Enjoy the ride for what it is. reviewText: Pegg, Frost and director Gregory Wright (absent here) have previously given us British metapop confections Spaced, Shaun of the Dead and Hot Fuzz. With Superbad director Greg Mottola subbing for Wright here, the action moves to America, and while things take awhile to really get going, the result is another humourous meditation on American pop culture -- in this case, centered on alien contact and invasion movies.Pegg and Frost play an aspiring artist and science-fiction writer respectively, delighted to have taken a vacation from England to go to the mega-geeky San Diego Comicon and then onwards for a vacation touring famous science-fiction and UFO landmarks across the Southwest in a rented motorhome. Their characters are more genial and less sharp-edged than we've seen them assay before, fitting for a movie that's ultimately more genial and less sharp-edged than we've seen them do before. The whole enterprise is really quite warm-hearted -- there are villains, but almost no one gets killed. Almost.Stopping to check out a car wreck in the desert, the two meet up with Paul, an alien who looks like a traditional Gray and talks like, well, Seth Rogen when he's being genial and funny, as opposed to Seth Rogen when he's mailing it in or Seth Rogen in a part Seth Rogen isn't really equipped to play. After much confusion and several faintings, the two agree to drive Paul to his retrieval area.Paul's been stuck on Earth since he crashed his spaceship near Roswell, New Mexico in 1947. The U.S. military abducted him then, and he's since been helping both them and Hollywood out with various alien ideas (he consulted on both E.T. and The X-Files) under the mistaken impression that he's a guest of the U.S. government. However, his technological and cultural knowhow exhausted after 60+ years, Paul is now expendable -- the powers that be want to dissect him to find out how his healing and invisibility powers work. Luckily, a sympathetic government agent managed warn him of his coming vivisection; Paul escaped; the government now pursues.The somewhat unlikely trio proceed to have adventures as they attempt to get Paul off-planet ahead of government pursuit. Along the way, they pick up a fourth party member played by Kristen Wiig -- a socially backward fundamentalist Christian creationist they have to kidnap from a trailer park lest she reveal their location and plans to the government. Luckily, Paul's telepathic powers show her that the universe is actually more than 6000 years old and that "eyes didn't just happen!", and she becomes a foul-mouthed agnostic with a driving need to lose her virginity to Pegg's character.The whole thing's a lot of fun, especially if you've seen the TV episodes and movies Paul refers to both explicitly and in passing. There are also some nice background bits of business, some surprisingly funny stoner comedy, and maybe a few too many jokes about Paul's junk.

reviewText: Graeme Willy (Simon Pegg) and Clive Gollings (Nick Frost) are two English nerds taking a road trip across America to see all the sites where alien activity has been reported. After a quick stop through Comic-Con, they embark on their trip and shortly into their excursion they meet Paul (voiced by Seth Rogen), an alien who has escaped from Area 51 and intends to return to his home planet. He enlists the reluctant Graeme and Clive to give him a ride and they embark on the journey to get Paul to his mother-ship. En route, they unwittingly kidnap Ruth Buggs (Kristen Wiig), a Creationist, whose glimpse of Paul more than challenges her beliefs. In addition to Ruth's father Moses (John Carroll Lynch) chasing after them, they also have government agent Zoil (a stone-faced Jason Bateman) and FBI agents Haggard (Bill Hader) and O'Reilly (Joe Lo Truglio) hot on their trail.Pegg and Frost previously collaborated with Edgar Wright for the hit films Shaun of the Dead and Hot Fuzz, which were comedic homages to zombie movies and cop movies, respectively. Paul follows the same formula of genre-spoofing and is, in many ways, the next logical step after those two films, yet it exists as a separate entity. While Pegg and Frost wrote the script, directing duties are handled by Greg Mottola (director of Superbad and Adventureland), who likely had a hand in shaping the humor of the film as his influence is apparent in the casting and overall tone. Audiences haven't responded to Paul as strongly as they did to Pegg and Frost's previous outings and it's true that this is a much more run-of-the-mill comedy, but that doesn't mean it's generic. It still has Pegg and Frost's comedic sensibility and wit and is more amusing and fun than it's been given credit for.Both Simon Pegg and Frost have described Paul as a love letter to Steven Spielberg and, in some ways, this makes it the comedic cousin of this year's Super 8. Unlike that film however, Paul doesn't just reference/homage Spielberg. The film has pop-culture references galore, with the majority relating to science-fiction and comic books. These references, visual and spoken, obvious and subtle, will be most enjoyed by fanboys but the casual viewer won't feel alienated. References to science-fiction/comic culture don't stop at the plot, but influenced the casting as well. Spielberg himself makes a voice appearance and an icon of the sci-fi genre makes one of the great "I should've seen it coming" entrances I've seen in some time. Even Blythe Danner (who it's nice to see in a non-Meet the Parents role) was likely cast because of her participation in the first X-Files movie.The cast is marvelous, with Pegg and Frost (best friends in real life) carrying the film with an onscreen chemistry that makes the film's message about friendship more poignant. With this film and Bridesmaids, Kristen Wiig is establishing herself as a star comedienne. Bateman, Hader, and Truglio are great as you'd expect, but there are hidden gems in the performances that can't be overlooked such as Jeffrey Tambor's small, but memorable role as science-fiction writer Adam Shadowchild and John Carroll Lynch's hilarious turn as Moses.The character Paul has physical characteristics that mirror the accepted look of an alien life form, but isn't much of an alien. This may be because he is voiced by Seth Rogen, who also played the character via motion capture until shooting The Green Hornet made it necessary for Truglio to step in. Rogen doesn't just provide the voice of Paul; Paul is Rogen and they share the same vocal facility, physical mannerisms, and character traits. Aside from looking like an alien and having alien abilities, Paul is basically Seth Rogen. I only mention this because some people seem to have a problem with Rogen and if you're expecting him to stretch his range as an actor, this isn't the place to look for that. While he may not stray from his persona, he does give an inspired vocal performance.Much of the humor comes from the pop-cultural references, but Paul is characterized by a broad spectrum of comedy that has elements of religious, political, gross-out, and satirical humor. What's better is that it is all bitingly clever and has my favorite throwaway line of the year (a reference to a certain 90s documentary directed by Andrew Jarecki). My readings on the internet boards for this film (never a place to go to read anything of worth) have revealed misguided controversy about the film's shots at religion. Yes, the film does ridicule religious beliefs but the jokes are pretty tame. What's more, they're aimed not at innocent churchgoers but satirical religious zealots who attempt to force their message onto anyone whom they come across. In context, these jokes don't poke fun at religion so much as closed-mindedness. Are these jokes essential to the plot? No. Are they funny? I thought so.Paul is a comedy that would not exist without the films that came before it and as such is predictable, but it can hardly be faulted for this. It's entertaining with a consistently amusing tone and some laugh-out-loud and subtly brilliant humor throughout. It's essentially a buddy/road comedy that happens have an alien, whose function is that of a "buddy" anyway.Spielberg's early films are the reason summer blockbusters are released every year. What's so great about Paul, along with Super 8, is that it's a direct descendant of those early Spielberg films but creates something wholly entertaining and fun. These films hearken back to when films were influenced by Spielberg's early films themselves rather than the business model they created. Paul made money at the U.S. box office but has been overshadowed by other comedies this year. It's not a profound comedy classic, but it's a nostalgic, satirical sci-fi comedy with a hilarious cast.GRADE: B+

reviewText: OVERVIEW:  The 2011 science-fiction/comedy, “Paul,” was directed by Greg Mottola and co-written by Simon Pegg, Nick Frost, and Seth Rogen.  Inspired by their mutual adoration for Steven Spielberg’s “E.T. the Extra Terrestrial” and “Close Encounters of the Third Kind,” Pegg and Frost first conceived the premise for “Paul” while on the set of “Shaun of the Dead” in 2003.  “Paul” allowed its creators the opportunity to incorporate numerous references from their favorite sci-fi movies.  Steven Spielberg, himself, makes a cameo appearance in the film during a “flashback to the 80s” scene; his voice is heard discussing ideas for the upcoming release of “E.T. the Extra Terrestrial,” retroactively insinuating that Paul, the alien, was the actual inspiration for E.T.  The film has been received positively by critics and audiences alike; it currently holds a 71% rating from Rotten Tomatoes.  Personally, I wouldn’t count “Paul” among its writers’ best or funniest works (I’d name “Hot Fuzz as #1), but I do think it fits in well with Pegg and Frost’s previous comedies.  What sets “Paul” apart is that it utilizes a more dynamic storyline than is generally used by its creators.  In some ways, the more intricate plotting grants “Paul” greater distinction and credit as a film than, say, “Shaun of the Dead,” but this element also detracts from the ‘silliness’ Pegg and Frost fans have come to expect from their movies.  All-in-all, I’m happy to have “Paul” in my collection of DVDs.STARRING ROLES:  Seth Rogen as the voice of Paul, Simon Pegg as Graeme Willy, Nick Frost as Clive Gollings, Kristen Wiig as Ruth Buggs, Jason Bateman as Special Agent Lorenzo Zoil, Bill Hader as Agent Haggard, Jane Lynch as Pat Stevens, Blythe Danner as Tara Walton, Joe Lo Truglio as Agent O’Reilly, David Koechner as Gus, Sigourney Weaver as “The Big Guy,” Jeffrey Tambor as famous sci-fi writer Adam Shadowchild, and John Carroll Lynch as Moses Buggs.SPECIAL FEATURES:  (1-disc/Unrated/214-min. Run-Time/ASIN:  B0050PYNP8)▪  Filmmakers’ Commentary with Greg Mottola, Simon Pegg, Nick Frost, Bill Hader, and Nira Park▪  Bloopers▪  The Evolution of Paul▪  Simon’s Silly Faces▪  Who the Hell is Adam Shadowchild?▪  Galleries and CreditsSUMMARY:  For the better part of a century, the U.S. government has been holding an extraterrestrial by the name of Paul as a hostage.  We learn that many of the 20th Century’s greatest technological advancements were not the products of humans at all, but were rather the fruits of Paul’s willingness to share information with his captors in exchange for being allowed to live.  When Paul’s “usefulness” runs dry, the government decides to kill him in order to harvest his brain and, hopefully, discover how to incorporate some of Paul’s unique physical abilities (invisibility camouflage and healing powers) into the human genome.  With the help of a friend inside the agency, Paul contacts his home planet to send a rescue ship to Earth; he flees the secret government base in a stolen vehicle.Two British tourists, Graeme and Clive, are on an RV trip visiting some of the U.S.’s most famous ‘close-encounter’ sites.  When Paul speeds past the RV, then crashes, Graeme and Clive pull over to check on the motorist.  Fascinated at the chance to meet a real alien, Graeme offers Paul a ride.  The trio stops for a layover at Moses Buggs’ RV park; Moses and his daughter, Ruth (who wears an eye-patch to conceal a blind eye), are devout fundamentalist Christians.Special Agent Lorenzo Zoil arrives at the scene of Paul’s wrecked vehicle.  He informs his boss, “The Big Guy,” that he’s picked up Paul’s trail; in order to resolve the matter as quickly and quietly as possible, “The Big Guy” attaches two additional agents, Haggard and O’Reilly, to the case.While collecting the campers’ fee, Ruth engages in a heated theological debate aboard Clive and Graeme’s RV.  After losing patience with Ruth’s ignorance, Paul reveals himself to her and later, via telepathy, shares his knowledge of the universe with Ruth.  When Moses discovers Paul, he presumes him to be a demon and chases the campers out of the park with his shotgun.  Ruth, torn between her father’s faith and knowledge of the outside world, is now along for the ride in the RV; Paul uses his healing powers to repair Ruth’s eye and, in the process, gains her trust.The remainder of the movie centers around concealing Paul from the public, evading the agents pursuing Paul, and making it to the rendezvous point so that Paul may be rescued.  There are a lot of laughs, some ‘eye-opening’ moments, and a few twists along the way, so I won’t spoil anything!

reviewText: This movie has some hilarious moments, especially if you are a fan of sci-fi movies, and even more especially if you are a fan of alien movies. It alternates between spoofing (affectionately) and paying homage to many classics, including of course all the biggies - E.T., Close Encounters of the Third Kind, Star Wars, Star Trek, Aliens, etc.. It is kind of like what Scream is to horror movies in that sense, but much smarter in most parts. I say 'most parts' because it also has some of the lower gross-out humor that the director (Greg Mottola of Superbad) and the star (Seth Rogan) are known for in other material, and that's not really my favorite kind of comedy. So this film worked best for me when it was in its smarter, referential/spoofing mode.The plot centers around a U.S. road trip by two Brits (played by Simon Pegg and Nick Frost), to Comic-Con (the ultimate sci-fi/comic book convention) and then to various UFO sighting spots around the southwest (Roswell, etc.) Along the way they encounter Paul, the alien voiced by Seth Rogan. They also pick up Kristin Wiig, playing a Christian Fundamentalist (which enables some creationist vs. evolutionist humor) and are chased by 'men in black' headed up by Jason Batemen. All the performances are great.It does drag in parts, so that is why for me it's a 4 not a 5 star (in addition to not being a fan of the gross-out sections.) But overall, this is a great, funny movie for anyone that likes sci-fi and/or Seth Rogan type humor. If not, it might not be for you.
summary: Funny As a Sci-Fi/Alien Movie Spoof, Although Misses on Some Jokes

reviewText: Having followed the guys for a few years now, I have to say, I wasn't particularly impressed with 'Hot Fuzz'. Yes, that production had all the Wright/Pegg/Frost styling, but the energy - the juice just wasn't there; the laughs few.With 'Paul' the boys finally recaptured the essence of 'Shaun of the Dead'. That creative spark of taking an iconic symbol and completely turning it on its head. Loved every minute of it!This flick can so easily become the 'Geek Test' of the new decade. A test I embarrassingly passed with flying colors - having seen and/or noted at least two dozen classic references. The best of which is the Mos Eisley Cantina scene. But there are so many more, I'm certain I must've missed at least a few. Director Greg Mottola did such an amazing job of working them all in. Kudos dude - you rock!Could Seth Rogan's smartass extra-terrastrial be any funnier?! Insanely hilarious! The guy had me tears with one liners that cannot be submitted here on Amazon - or repeated at your grandmother's house. But one bit, which occurs at the very end of the film, comes from Jane 'I Thought You'd Be Taller' Lynch. After a throwaway joke about seeing the female lead, Kristin Wiig's character naked, she responds completely deadpan: "I'd like that." The look on Kristin's face! BWAHAHAHA! Priceless!And perhaps in his best big screen gig, Jason Bateman. He showed a maturity that I've never seen before. Having lived in the shadow of his smarmy former child star career for so long, I believed that he could never get beyond it. I'm happy to say that I was wrong. My view changed a bit when he did 'Hancock'. But playing cold-hearted MIB Agent Lorenzo Zoil (say it out loud a few times <laughing>) he truly felt like a zombified state functionary bent on success at all costs. Completely fantastic performance.I won't reveal too much of the plot - it would spoil it for new viewers. Hopefully, even non-geeks will "get" this film.My very deep appreciation to Simon Pegg and Nick Frost - you guys have made my year. Thank you. All in all an outstanding comedy/action flick and well worth the time and funds spent. In fact, after this review, I'm off to watch it again. <g>Movie Note: I screened the Unrated Version of the film. So that version may contain differing or deleted scenes from the theatrical version which I have yet to view.Personal Note: Why were there sailors in Wyoming? <laughing s'more> X-D

reviewText: Simon Pegg and Nick Frost, those lovable Brits from "Shaun of the Dead" and "Hot Fuzz", are back. Pegg and Frost star as Graeme Willy and Clive Gollings, two grown-up nerds who've come to America for Comic-Con and a tour of all the famous alien hot spots. It's the ultimate nerd "holiday", as they would call it. What they didn't expect, was actually coming across an alien, which of course is what happens. The alien is Paul (voiced by Seth Rogen): he's on the run from the FBI, and he really needs a ride in their RV.Ironically, part of what makes the character of Paul so unique is just how normal he seems to be, which is as refreshing as it is unlikely. The character of Paul is basically if Seth Rogen was an alien, which again, is totally fine with me. There's something comforting about Paul being essentially human in nature, yet not at all; he's cool, easygoing, down to earth (pun intended). He smokes (cigarettes and weed), swears, gets drunk, and references pop culture. It's hard not to like Paul.Simon Pegg and Nick Frost have built-in chemistry, and Rogen sidles in to the mix quite nicely. Overall though, there begins to be too many supporting players, with Kristen Wiig tagging along as the evolution-denying religious nutcase (she has a t-shirt with Jesus shooting Charles Darwin), the three FBI agents on their tail, two rednecks (three if you count Wiig's dad), and Jane Lynch, Blythe Danner and Sigourney Weaver all making small appearances. None of these people give bad performances (Bill Hader is predictably hilarious as the bumbling FBI agent), but a lot of times I just wanted more focus on the three stars of the film.The movie does get caught up a couple times in lambasting religion, but at least it doesn't hijack the plot (I'm looking at you, "Invention of Lying"). And the stereotypical bible-toting, shotgun-bearing redneck comes close to ruining the whole thing. Like Paul says, "Whatever, dude". Overall, the movie "Paul" is a lot like its title character. It's goofy, light-hearted, maybe a bit thin, but overall a great time and leaves you with a smile on your face.

reviewText: There simply aren't enough movies like Paul made today.  A seethingly irreverant comedy from a collective of various comedic minds that features enough sci-fi/comic in-jokes and nods that any fan of the genre can't help but love this film.  Shaun of the Dead co-stars Simon Pegg and Nick Frost star as a pair of British fanboys hanging out in the states for ComicCon, only to wind up lending a ride to a cigarette smoking, wise cracking alien named Paul (voiced by Seth Rogen).  Paul seeks to return home after crashing on Earth back in the 40s and being used as a tool by the government, who now view him as a liability.  On their trail is a relentless secret agent (Jason Bateman) among others, which only adds to the surprisingly non-stop hilarity and occasional slapstick humor.  Paul has it all for a film: laughs, misadventures, surprises, and an even more surprising amount of heart behind it that really sets it apart from any other recent film that can fit any or all of these types of genres.  That, as well as a just plain awesome cast that also includes Kristin Wiig, Bill Hader, Jeffrey Tambor, Blythe Danner, and the great Sigourney Weaver really help make Paul shine.  All in all, you need to check out Paul at the very least, you will not be disappointed one bit.

reviewText: As of writing, this film isn't out in Canada, however a CAM version of the UK release is out, so I am reviewing it based on the version I saw.When it comes to Brit comedy, nobody does it quite like the Frost/Pegg duo. Both are phenomenal actors and seeing them on screen is a charm. So when I saw the trailer for "Paul" with The Green Hornet,, I must say I was very excited. And I must say, the film didn't disappoint. Is it quite on the same level as the Blood and Ice Cream movies? Definitely not, but it's a great piece of brain popcorn and I believe you will definitely love it.This movie is basically the plot of E.T. with the humour of Hot Fuzz and Shaun of the Dead, and it works! Of course you can't go wrong with that combination. Although Edgar Wright didn't direct the film, and the film feels very different from the mentioned two, this film actually manages to have the same level of charm and entertainment as those two. Also, the film has a wide range of good actors- including Jason Bateman, Jane Lynch, and even David Koechner!Two British nerds, Graeme and Clive, are on a road trip across the US, which they have been dreaming of as kids. They've been dreaming of this as kids, and the highlight so far has been Comic Con San Diego. Theyeven have met Adam Shadowchild. One night, while in Area 51, Nevada, they witness a car crash, and come across the foul-mouthed alien slacker Paul. But this ain't no District 9 or E.T. Paul is, as mentioned above, is a slacker, and a loud/foul mouth. He is being chased by US government agents, and Graeme and Clive have no choice butto take them with him. Along the way, they pick up a religious chick, an old lady who was wronged by Paul, and it all becomes one wacky and zany adventure.This is definitely an adults-only version of E.T., and one that manages to entertain all the way through. Tonnes of gross moments and WTF moments as well as belly laughs and crude humour. Seth Rogen issurprisingly great as the said alien Paul, his voice is surprisingly fitting. He was great in his past year's The Green Hornet, and he does amazingly well here. Pegg and Frost are their usual charming selves,and manage to make a great team. But the highlight of the movie was Kristen Wiig- she was HILARIOUS!!!! Every line from her mouth was gold, and she definitely stole the show. This movie also had lots of heart too, and there is a VERY touching scene near the end I will not spoil.Overall, this definitely is not Wright material, but if you go into it with an open mind, you will enjoy this movie like I did. Definitely recommended for sure.
summary: Hot Fuzz and E.T. had a baby and its head popped off!

reviewText: I am revising my review.  At first, I reviewed it with three stars because of the profuse cussing.However, I am giving it 5 stars based on its own merit.  I actually enjoy this movie very much!  The more I watch it, the more I like it.  The directing is awesome and the movie rings of all the past Spielberg movies we know from Duel, Jaws, ET, Close Encounters of the Third Kind, and Star Wars - all wrapped up in a road trip with two British Graphic Comic pros and an Alien.The movie does rub up against the current understanding of ET phenomenon and religion.  It poses an angle that Aliens "believe in" evolution while mass populations of the human race believe in misguided religion.  These are topics that frequent the UFO community.  This movie handles the topic without any shyness in the matter, portraying the religious characters as misguided and brainwashed while the Alien appears to be an Evolutionist.  Paul, the Alien at one point screams out "Oh My God! My Gosh!" so perhaps he is not an Atheist after all.  But the God concept is left where it is at and is a prominent layer, one of many layers, in the movie.  The movie is cleverly written, full of continual entertainment from one exciting scene to the next.I appreciate the amazing motion capture and the excellent computer graphic animation.  The details of Paul, right down to the skin textures, lines, blood vessels, etc., is phenomenal.  Paul is very "human like" in that he bubbles with a raw "down-to-earth" personality that challenges the frayed nerves of his companions, Graeme and Clive.The movie is full of laughs and has lots of exciting action. The writing and story line is great and the characters are so perfect and believable.For once, FINALLY, we have an "Alien" movie that does not portray Aliens as freaky insects, monsters, or evil beings that want to take over the world and eat peoples' brains out. Paul is approachable, friendly, and full of life, even though he is rude and disgusting at times.Graeme and Clive are swept away and become fugitives with Paul as they end up on the run from the secret government Black Ops agents who want him dead!  Even the agents are not without wit and are likeable to some degree.  This is a great cast of characters and everything fits extremely well and the story is sequenced great and tight.  Great job!It is a great movie if you can handle the uncontrolled four letter words that come up in every scene.  Once you get past that, it carries itself.I wish it would have been made without all that cussing.  I hope they make a tamer version of it and dub in different explicatives.  Men in Black and Raiders of the Lost Ark, all the other great action movies were able to carry the movie fantastically without foul language and I hope if this movie is ever re-mixed, it would step up to the plate and make a version with a clean mouth.
